DOCNAME: CASE OF KRUMPEL AND KRUMPELOVA v. SLOVAKIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses (domestic proceedings) - claim dismissed
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants are spouses . They were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicants concluded a contract with PERSON , the owner of a building company . PERSON undertook to sell a plot of land to the applicants and to build a family house for them . The applicants paid CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) to PERSON
CARDINAL . M. failed to comply with the contract . The applicants therefore revoked it on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants sued the company of ORG before PERSON . On DATE the court discontinued the proceedings as the applicants had not paid the court fee .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE criminal proceedings were brought against PERSON as he was suspected of fraud . The applicants declared that they wished to claim damages from PERSON in the context of the criminal proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants sued PERSON for damages before ORG . On DATE ORG discontinued the proceedings . The decision stated , with reference to LAW of ORG , that the applicants had also claimed damages in the context of the criminal proceedings against PERSON and that those criminal proceedings were pending . On DATE an appellate court dismissed the applicants’ appeal .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , a public prosecutor froze property of ORG ’s company , the value of which corresponded to SKK CARDINAL , with a view to securing the claims of CARDINAL aggrieved persons .
CARDINAL . On DATE CARDINAL PERSON ’s mother returned SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL to the applicants . In a written statement of CARDINAL DATE PERSON admitted his debt in respect of the applicants .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the charges against M. were enlarged to comprise economic offences which had no bearing on the applicants’ claim and which the accused had allegedly committed in the context of the dissolution of the former NORP and GPE .
CARDINAL . Following the enlargement of the charges against PERSON his bank account was blocked in the context of the criminal proceedings .
The Government submitted that the sum blocked amounted to SKK CARDINAL .

The applicants submitted , with reference to an article published in a DATE , that ORG had given his consent , in DATE , to unblock the account in which approximately SKK CARDINAL millions had been deposited . The article further states that most of the money had subsequently been transferred abroad . In another article published in the same weekly ORG confirmed that he had intended to start disciplinary proceedings against ORG in that regard . However , the prosecutor had resigned from his post .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG indicted PERSON before ORG . On DATE ORG returned the case to the public prosecutor for further investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicants made a written submission to ORG which was dealing with the criminal charges against ORG interpreted the submission as a civil claim for damages and transferred it to ORG .
CARDINAL . A new indictment against PERSON was filed with ORG on DATE . The indictment concerned numerous offences and , in addition to PERSON , CARDINAL other persons .
CARDINAL . On DATE the criminal judge decided to deal separately with several aspects of the case , including those which were relevant for the determination of the applicants’ claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE a ORG judge informed the applicants , in reaction to their above submission of DATE , that criminal proceedings against PERSON were still pending and that LAW prevented the court from dealing with a civil action for damages in the same case . The applicants were invited to inform the court whether they maintained their action and were instructed how to rectify formal shortcoming in their submission .

CARDINAL . In a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicants replied that their above letter of DATE had been meant for the judges dealing with the charges against PERSON and that they were aware that they could not have separate civil proceedings for damages brought against PERSON as the criminal proceedings against him were still pending .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the applicants complained to ORG about a violation of their right to a hearing without unjustified delay .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Považská Bystrica ORG judge informed ORG about the contents of her above letter to the applicants of CARDINAL DATE . No reference was made to the applicants’ reply of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint as being manifestly ill - founded . The decision states :

“ It follows from ... the submission of ORG that , at present , proceedings are pending before it upon the initiative of the [ applicants ] ... The subject - matter of those proceedings is the claim for damages against [ M. ] which the applicants have also submitted in the context of the criminal proceedings before ORG . The applicants therefore have , provided that they overcome the obstacle of litis pendens and bring their [ civil ] action in compliance with the formal requirements as instructed by ORG , a different effective remedy at their disposal in the context of proceedings before a civil court ...

In ORG view , an action for damages is an effective remedy in respect of [ the applicants ] , as a [ civil ] claim for compensation by persons who have suffered damage may form the basis of their own case in respect of which ( unlike persons who join criminal proceedings with a claim for damages ) they enjoy the guarantee of ... a hearing without undue delay ...

It follows that the alleged failure of ORG to proceed with [ the criminal case against PERSON ] speedily can have no bearing on the applicants’ constitutional right to a hearing without undue delay ... In the circumstances , it is the applicants’ claim for damages which is to be considered as their case ; determination of such a claim is not the purpose of the criminal proceedings and , in addition , the applicants can claim damages before a civil court provided that they comply with the statutory requirements ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted PERSON in proceedings concerning the charges which were not related to the ORG claim . PERSON was sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and the court ordered him to compensate MONEY to ORG . The convicted persons appealed and the proceedings are pending before ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP ORG is expected to start determining the remaining charges against PERSON ( which concern fraud in respect of CARDINAL individuals including the applicants ) in the course of DATE .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) provides , inter alia , that a person who has suffered damage , as a result of a criminal offence , can claim compensation from the accused person and request that the court , in a judgment convicting the accused person , order the latter to compensate for such damage .

CARDINAL . NORP In criminal cases falling within the jurisdiction of regional courts , the court decides , according to the nature of the matter under consideration , whether or not an injured person should be allowed to participate in the proceedings ( LAW ) ) . Such decision is taken , as a rule , at the main hearing . In accordance with ORG case - law , an injured party may be prevented from participating in the proceedings for important reasons only , for example where it is required for protection of a ORG secret .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a claim for damages may be secured , up to an amount corresponding to the estimated damage , on the property of the accused where a justified fear exists that compensation for damage caused as a result of an offence will be jeopardised or rendered difficult .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW ) , where a court convicts the accused person of an offence as a result of which damage to third persons was caused , it shall , as a rule , order the convicted person to compensate for such damage , provided that the relevant claim was filed in time .

CARDINAL . Under LAW ) , a criminal court shall refer a person claiming damages to a civil court where the evidence available is not sufficient for determining that claim or where the taking of further evidence exceeding the scope of the criminal case is required and the criminal proceedings would be thereby unduly prolonged .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that , once proceedings have been brought , no other judicial proceedings can be instituted in the same matter .

CARDINAL . In accordance with ORG practice under this provision , the filing of a claim for damages in the context of criminal proceedings is to be considered as the bringing of proceedings , within the meaning of the relevant provisions of LAW , and it constitutes an obstacle of litis pendens where a civil action is filed after the corresponding claim has been submitted in the context of criminal proceedings ( ORG Decisions and Opinions , CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) .
